column4: Hi, so I have ubuntu 11.04 32bit, and I want to upgrade it to 64bit. Can I do this without a cd/usb drive??
you need to fresh install somehow
Ok, an dhow about this, I have 4.5GB ram installed on my comp, and it oly detects 3.5
you're using 32bit
yeah, but it should be able to detect at least 4
it's memory minus 1GB with PAE
plus PAE is 3-6% slower all the time, install 64bit is best suggestion
Ok, so how do I upgrade to 64bit without a cd/usb drive??
? but you have to fresh install somehow
but I dont have a usb drive, and my CD drive doesnt work
the likely answer is YOU can't (network boot is theoretically possible, but WAY non-trivial.  AND you'd need a second box to act as a server)
What if I took out 0.5GB ram, leaving me with 4gb, would that give me 4GB or 3?
3.  PAE requires 1GB for kernel or something.  I don't use PAE, i use 64bit - i consider PAE a dirty-"hack"
ok, ill upgrade
As you may know, the USB-creator is REALLY messed up. Would you happen to know if I can just extract the iso onto the usb drive??
unetbootin!!!
huh?/
it's a program to put ISOs onto USB - REALLY handy!
It keeps freezing on my compo
um, that's too bad.  Sorry man.
Can I just extract the iso and put tthe files on the usb stick??
not really.  The next ubuntu will probably catch up to debian and have hybrid images, which will make life a lot easier.
